title: Role of miRNAs in brown and white adipose tissue differentiation and function
descriptions:
Abstract:

The project titled "Role of miRNAs in brown and white adipose tissue differentiation and function" addresses the critical role of microRNAs (miRNAs) in the regulation of adipose tissues, which are integral to energy homeostasis and metabolic health. Given the distinct metabolic roles of brown adipose tissue (BAT) and white adipose tissue (WAT), our research aims to delineate the miRNAs that direct their differentiation and function. 

White adipose tissue is crucial for energy storage in the form of triglycerides and regulates whole-body homeostasis. In contrast, brown adipose tissue specializes in lipid catabolism and thermogenesis. Dysregulation of WAT can lead to ectopic lipid storage and severe pathology, while enhanced BAT function is associated with increased energy expenditure and a lean, healthy phenotype. This proposal seeks to identify and distinguish the miRNAs involved in the development and function of these tissues, establish miRNA expression signatures, and elucidate their molecular mechanisms.

Utilizing both in vitro and in vivo systems, including lineage tracing studies and transgenic animal models, along with cohorts of human patients, our research will explore the origin of beige cells within subcutaneous adipose tissue (SAT) and establish their significance in metabolism regulation. Further, we aim to develop strategies to promote brown fat differentiation and function, potentially offering novel therapeutic approaches for metabolic disorders.

The research will also involve targeted miRNA silencing in BAT to investigate its functional role and examine potential treatments for dyslipidemia, diabetes, and obesity. By uncovering the underlying regulatory networks, we aspire to contribute to the growing body of knowledge in adipose biology and enhance the prospects for clinical interventions in metabolic diseases.

Abstract

Title: Role of miRNAs in Brown and White Adipose Tissue Differentiation and Function

The prevalence of metabolic disorders such as dyslipidemia, diabetes, and obesity is rising globally, necessitating the development of novel therapeutic strategies. This grant proposal focuses on elucidating the role of microRNAs (miRNAs) in the differentiation and function of two distinct types of adipose tissue: brown (BAT) and white (WAT) adipose tissues. BAT is specialized in lipid catabolism and heat production, primarily induced by cold exposure and diet, while WAT primarily regulates whole-body homeostasis and stores energy as triglycerides. The disruption of WAT can lead to ectopic lipid storage and severe pathology, whereas increased BAT development is associated with a lean and healthy phenotype, increased energy expenditure, and no dysfunction in other tissues.

Our research goals are to identify the miRNAs and other factors that regulate the differentiation and function of BAT and WAT, distinguish miRNAs that are specific to brown or white adipogenesis, establish unique miRNA signatures for each cell type, and elucidate the molecular mechanisms by which miRNAs regulate adipose tissue differentiation and metabolism. Furthermore, we aim to investigate the origin and significance of beige cells within subcutaneous adipose tissue (SAT) and their role in metabolism regulation in vivo. Our approach includes a combination of in vitro and in vivo systems, lineage tracing studies, transgenic animal models, and cohorts of human patients.

The ultimate objectives are to develop strategies that can induce brown fat differentiation and function, potentially leading to increased energy expenditure and a healthier body composition, as well as to discover methods to silence miRNAs exclusively in brown fat, which could result in new treatments for metabolic diseases. This research is poised to make significant contributions to the understanding of adipose tissue biology and the development of innovative strategies to combat metabolic disorders.

Abstract:

Title: Role of miRNAs in Brown and White Adipose Tissue Differentiation and Function

The proposed research seeks to elucidate the critical roles of microRNAs (miRNAs) in the differentiation and function of brown (BAT) and white adipose tissue (WAT), key regulators of energy metabolism. Brown adipose tissue, known for lipid catabolism and heat production, is induced by factors such as cold exposure and diet. In contrast, white adipose tissue maintains whole-body homeostasis and stores energy in the form of triglycerides. Disruption in WAT's function can lead to ectopic lipid storage and severe pathology, while an increase in BAT is associated with beneficial outcomes such as increased energy expenditure and a lean, healthy phenotype.

The project will identify the miRNAs and other factors that regulate BAT and WAT differentiation and function, distinguish miRNAs specific to brown or white adipogenesis, and establish miRNA signatures for each cell type. Furthermore, we aim to uncover the molecular mechanisms through which miRNAs influence adipose tissue differentiation and metabolism, including the determination of the origin of beige cells within subcutaneous adipose tissue (SAT) and their importance in vivo metabolism regulation.

The research will employ both in vitro and in vivo systems, including lineage tracing studies, the use of transgenic animals, and cohorts of human patients to validate findings and ensure relevance to human health. One of the project's pivotal goals is to develop strategies to induce brown fat differentiation and function, which could lead to innovative treatment approaches for metabolic disorders such as dyslipidemia, diabetes, and obesity. Additionally, the proposal includes the exploration of methods to selectively silence miRNAs in brown fat, an intervention with potential therapeutic benefits.

In conclusion, this proposal aims to provide a comprehensive understanding of the miRNA-mediated regulatory mechanisms in adipose tissue, promising to inform the development of targeted treatments for metabolic diseases.

Abstract:

Title: Role of miRNAs in Brown and White Adipose Tissue Differentiation and Function

This grant proposal focuses on the significant role of microRNAs (miRNAs) in the differentiation and functional regulation of brown (BAT) and white adipose tissue (WAT), vital components in the body's energy balance and metabolic regulation. While WAT is primarily involved in storing energy as triglycerides and maintaining whole body homeostasis, BAT is responsible for lipid catabolism and thermogenesis. Dysregulation of these adipose tissues leads to metabolic disorders such as ectopic lipid storage and severe pathology, whereas increased BAT activity is associated with a lean and healthy phenotype through heightened energy expenditure without affecting other tissues.

The overarching goal of our research is to identify miRNAs and other factors that are crucial in regulating BAT and WAT differentiation and function. We aim to (1) distinguish miRNAs that are specifically involved in brown or white adipogenesis and expressed in their respective precursors, (2) establish miRNA expression signatures for either cell type, and (3) elucidate the molecular mechanisms of miRNAs in the regulation of adipose tissue differentiation and metabolism. Additionally, we seek to investigate the origin of beige cells within subcutaneous adipose tissue (SAT) and their importance in metabolic regulation in vivo.

To achieve our objectives, we will utilize both in vitro and in vivo systems, including lineage tracing studies, the use of transgenic animals, and cohorts of human patients. This approach will allow us to develop strategies to induce BAT differentiation and function and discover methods to silence miRNAs exclusively in brown fat, with the potential to treat metabolic disorders such as dyslipidemia, diabetes, and obesity.

Our proposal promises to provide groundbreaking insights into adipose tissue biology and pave the way for novel therapeutic approaches targeting metabolic diseases, thus having a far-reaching impact on public health.
